private_information: I can only manipulate blocks labeled with vowels: A, E, I.
I can only pick up blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can only move one block at a time.
vowel_agent.goal: Contribute to the reconfiguration so that the blocks form the target single stack with L on the table and A on top.

private_information: I can only manipulate blocks labeled with consonants: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L.
I can only pick up blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can only move one block at a time.
consonant_agent.goal: Contribute to the reconfiguration so that the blocks form the target single stack with L on the table and A on top.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and must produce a final PDDL domain and problem for the FastDownward solver.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate the agents' local models and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem that achieves the global stacking goal using FastDownward.

public_information: There are twelve uniquely labeled blocks A B C D E F G H I J K L arranged in stacks on a table.
Agents may only move blocks that are at the top of a stack.
Moves consist of picking up a single top block and placing it on top of another stack or on the table.
One agent is restricted to manipulating vowel-labeled blocks A E I and the other agent is restricted to manipulating consonant-labeled blocks B C D F G H J K L.
Initial stacks are: Stack1 bottom-to-top E H I J K, Stack2 bottom-to-top G D L F C, Stack3 bottom-to-top A B.
The global goal is to create a single stack with L on the table and then K J I H G F E D C B A stacked above L in that order so that A is the topmost block.

local_model.system_prompt: You are the vowel agent. You can only manipulate vowel-labeled blocks A E I. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a concise machine readable summary of your local capabilities and local initial facts.
local_model.prompt: You are vowel_agent. Given the public information about the blockworld and your private information, produce a JSON object named vowel_model containing the following keys: controllable_blocks listing the vowel blocks you may manipulate, local_top_facts listing which of those blocks are currently at the top of a stack and on what, and allowed_actions describing the abstract move actions you can perform (pick-up and put-down) and any preconditions you require. Keep the output focused on facts and capabilities only.

local_model.system_prompt: You are the consonant agent. You can only manipulate consonant-labeled blocks B C D F G H J K L. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a concise machine readable summary of your local capabilities and local initial facts.
local_model.prompt: You are consonant_agent. Given the public information about the blockworld and your private information, produce a JSON object named consonant_model containing the following keys: controllable_blocks listing the consonant blocks you may manipulate, local_top_facts listing which of those blocks are currently at the top of a stack and on what, and allowed_actions describing the abstract move actions you can perform (pick-up and put-down) and any preconditions you require. Keep the output focused on facts and capabilities only.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Your job is to integrate the local models provided by the agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting the FastDownward planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem> and </problem> tags. Ensure actions remain distinct where appropriate and that the domain models the constraints that only top blocks can be moved and agent-specific controllability if needed.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. You will receive the vowel_model and consonant_model JSON objects produced by the agents. Use the public information about initial stacks and the global stacking goal to produce a final PDDL domain and PDDL problem suitable for FastDownward. The domain must define predicates for on block relationships, on-table, clear (top) status, holding if used, and actions to pick up and put down blocks. The problem must declare all blocks, the initial on/on-table/clear facts reconstructed from the provided models and public information, and the goal as a single stack with L on the table and the sequence K J I H G F E D C B A above it. Enclose the pddl domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the pddl problem between <problem> and </problem> tags. Do not include extraneous commentary.
